section.p: Malleus Deum favours a combat as war versus a combat as sport philosophy. That is if the players can avoid a fight or enter a fight with advantages due to planning then that is a good thing. Players should be attempting to tilt the balance of combat in their favour. The combat as sport approach has each fight an independent thing and it should be "fair" to both sides.
Magic items are rare. If everyone has a dozen magic items then they lose their specialness.

The goals of a game shape the gaming experience. It is one of the stated goals of Malleus Deum to deemphasize the role of combat in the game (compared with DnD). For this reason we do not award experience for like other games. In fact, Malleus Deum does not use experience points at all. Instead at certain points in the game the GM just states you go up a level. The GM should choose these points when story arcs have been resolved and the characters are facing some down time.

A Story Arc is a set of encounters that allow players to move their story forward. Encounters might be fights with the players nemeses or meetings that divulge key facts that the players need to solve a mystery.
The DM should use Foreshadowing to lead players into encounters.

The classical unities, Aristotelian unities, or three unities are rules for drama derived from a passage in Aristotle's Poetics. In their neoclassical form they are as follows:
unity of action: a play should have one action that it follows, with minimal subplots. unity of time: the action in a play should occur over a period of no more than 24 hours. unity of place: a play should exist in a single physical space and should not attempt to compress geography, nor should the stage represent more than one place.

subsection.p: Balance is a difficult thing to maintain in role-playing games. There are a number of alternative ways to achieve balance. Many games rely on the DM to achieve balance and he spends his time buffing the monsters or nerfing them to make encounters challenging. Combat can be fast and lethal though and all of a sudden the party might be in serious trouble purely due to unfortunate dice rolling.

Another approach is to have theoretical models of the players and the monsters powers. In this way you constrain the effects of combat to within well understood limits, reducing the lethality of combat. The problem with this type of combat is it typically results in slow slog-fests and favours having all encounters of equal difficulty which is rather dull.

Instead of balancing encounters our approach to this problem is to maintain the potential lethality of combat but to provide a series of Outs. An out is a way for the party to get out of their predicament. Outs are designed a priori. When the encounter is being constructed the DM should spend some time thinking of a few different outs if they can. Outs are not needed for non-lethal encounters.
As a DM, use your judgement designing outs. Try to think of a way out that is contextual, that makes sense. Tell the characters what is happening and allow them to get away somehow.
Force the players to run away if they won't. Force a party morale test - hopefully they'll fail and run away of their own accord. Compel characters with cowardly aspects to run.

Use a Luck roll or an Intelligence roll to provide the players with some advantage before you use an out. They might, luckily, see a key hanging on the wall or they might realize that this would be the room where a key might be stored. It's better if the players abilities save them rather than a deus ex machina.

Use Luck Checks to get the party out of danger or to keep the story moving forward. Only one player should be allowed to make a Luck Check in a particular circumstance -- if everyone is allowed to make a Luck Check then it will very likely succeed and the check will become meaningless.

Finally, if you can think of nothing better use one of the outs defined for the encounter. An out is a way to get the party out of immediate danger or to avoid a TPK in the event of a loss. For example:

list.li: In a town the town guards might turn up to help at a crucial moment.
If the party is fighting the town guards themselves then have the guards run away or throw the players in gaol.
If the players are fighting against slavers and they lose then they may wake up in the hold of a slave ship.
When fighting with Orcs they might be captured for sacrifice to one of their gods and or for eating at a later date.
When fighting a bear get the player with woodland law to roll and then explain that the bear is old, then have the bear die on the next hit.

subsection.p: If it becomes obvious to players that you are using outs then their actions become meaningless and they may lose interest. The advantage of outs is that because you know what your outs will be you can use foreshadowing to make saving the characters less heavy handed. For example, say the players will be fighting cultists, mention that ceremonially multilated bodies are being found following a full moon, when the players are wandering the streets mention how dark it is and that they will be unlikely to catch anyone in flagrante delicto as it is not even a full moon. Then if they are captured they will be imprisoned until the next full moon. Also have them meet the towns guard. The towns guard will be very curious about what they are doing in the streets. Later if the party is about to be overwhelmed by cultists the towns guard can show up without it feeling like the DMs just saved them.

section.p: For combat to be interesting strategically it is important that there be a chance of failure. However, as combat is highly lethal it may result in a total party kill, which is a generally undesirable outcome.

There are two approaches to solving this problem. The first is to make sure that the characters are able to win the combat by providing deliberately easy foes. While this works, if overused it leads to a dull combat experience.

The second approach to solving this problem is to provide an Out for the party should things go wrong. For example if the characters are fighting slavers and they lose then they can be enslaved and the game continues. If they are fighting Orcs they may be kept for food later. The city guards might throw them in the dungeon if they prevail against the party.

A sub-type of the Out is the Deus Ex Machina. In this case the party is saved right at the last minute by some third-party. This is generally undesirable from a narrative perspective as it leads the players to believe that whatever they do some third-party will save them at the last minute, thus reducing tension.

The trick to making Outs feel less contrived is Foreshadowing. As a GM, you should provide information to the characters about the Out so that if and when you have to use it the development in the narrative is less jarring. For example, if characters are trying to contact the elvish border guards in the Grey Forest and you, as the GM, know they are just about to run into giant spiders have the characters hear the guards trumpets in the distance. If the players are fighting slavers, let them know that there have been slaver raids taking place. Also it is a good idea to plant these foreshadowing seeds earlier rather than later.
In summary, to avoid combat annihilation try to have an Out for the characters before the combat. Use foreshadowing in order to make the out seem less contrived.

Balance is important in role-playing games. Not everything has to be balanced but it is important to know and make a conscious decision to make something imbalanced. Note that the effect of doing this can be far-reaching. Imbalance is also important if the players chance of success always remains the same they have no motivation to think outside the box in order to gain an advantage.
Default point cost should be around 5 per ability, most abilities total point cost should be in the range 3-7.
In order to balance play we have the following set of rules of thumb to allow us to maintain game balance.
High damage dealing characters should be able to kill a monster of their level in two turns on average. Non-combat specialist characters should be able to kill a monster in three turns on average.
Combat classes should hit on average two in three times. Non combatants should hit ever second attack.

We will choose
Combat centric characters deal: 5 hit points + 2*level when they hit.
Non combat characters deal: 3 hit points + 2*level
Monster armour class flows from those two
An average level skill should cost 5 skill points.

If skills require successes/attempts then they must have a Check defined. The check should include a DDC. If the check uses a dice pool the ability should also have an overcharge value. The overcharge should be a value relative to the DC used .. e.g. DC + 5.
